title-group.subtitle: An Application of Diversity and Integration Indices to Small Agencies

author-notes.corresp: Salomon A. Guajardo, Department of Public Management, John Jay College of Criminal Justice, City University of New York, 445 W. 59th Street, Room 3536, New York, NY 10019, USA. Email: sguajardo@jjay.cuny.edu

abstract.p: Over the past 40 years, the research on workforce diversity has increased significantly. Despite this increased research, little attention has been given to the application of diversity and integration indices to departments with small workforces. Even less attention has been given to inferences that are made based on the diversity or integration scores that are obtained from the application of diversity indices. These issues are important because human resources managers and administrators are likely to modify or implement diversity policies or initiatives based on the diversity scores they obtain. This article applies three diversity indices to departments with small workforces and evaluates how data aggregation affects diversity scores and the inferences made based on those scores.

body.p: Since about 1967, the measurement and analysis of minority integration (i.e., diversity) in public organizations has been a topic of significant interest and research to political scientists, public managers and personnel administrators.1 With the increased interest in minority integration2 and diversity3 in public organizations, researchers have either developed or used various indices to quantify the degree to which governmental agencies are integrated and subsequently diverse (Guajardo, 1999; Kellough, 1990; Meier, 1975; Nachmias & Rosenbloom, 1973; Starks, 2009). Despite the increased focus on minority and workforce diversity, little attention has been given to the application of integration and diversity indices to small agencies and their implications for human resources policies.

Before discussing the measurement of diversity and integration in public organizations, it is essential to present briefly the reasons why it is important to assess accurately the level of diversity within an organization. The reasons include the following:

list-item.p: Evaluate whether an organization’s diversity program and initiatives are accomplishing their goals.
Monitor minority integration and diversity trends for an organization and its departments monthly, quarterly, or annually.
Pinpoint areas within an organization where diversity trends are decreasing or increasing and understand why the trends are occurring.
Revise or strengthen existing human resources policies based on quantitative data that inform human resources administrators and executives regarding negative or positive outcomes.

body.p: When diversity or integration indices are applied to small public organizations, a number of measurement and policy issues come to the forefront. These include the following:

list-item.p: What effect does data aggregation have on an index score when racial or ethnic classifications are aggregated because of a lack of sufficient employment data?
What are the inferences that can be made regarding the level of diversity or integration when an index is applied to agencies with small workforces?
What are the human resources policy implications that result from applying a particular diversity or integration index to an agency with a small workforce?

body.p: From a policy making perspective, these issues are important because human resources managers and policy makers are likely to modify, update, or implement workforce diversity initiatives and policies without taking into full consideration the underlying employment data and the application of a particular index to the data.

sec.title: Review of the City of Fresno Employment Data
sec.p: As of February 2009, the City of Fresno,4 California, had a total staff of 4,971 (Table 1). The departments range from 1,318 employees to 7. As Table 1 shows, the Police Department is the largest department and the City Clerk’s Office is the smallest.

caption.p: Total Staff of the City of Fresno, California.

sec.p: With respect to the ethnic and racial composition of the workforce, Table 1 shows that Whites comprise the largest segment of the workforce followed by Hispanics, Asians, and Blacks. American Indians, Pacific Islanders, and those who did not specify a particular ethnic or racial group collectively comprise the remainder of the workforce. Table 2 shows the percent distribution by ethnic or racial category for the City of Fresno’s departments.

caption.p: Total Staff of the City of Fresno, California, by Percent.

sec.p: As illustrated in Tables 1 and 2, a number of departments employ few Blacks, American Indians, and Pacific Islanders. The data also show that a number of departments have not integrated American Indians or Pacific Islanders within their workforces. Only two departments (Public Utilities and Fire) have employees in each ethnic or racial group.

sec.title: Application of Diversity Indices to Small Agencies
sec.p: When the McIntosh, Lieberson, and MV indices are applied to the employment data summarized in Tables 1 and 2, the indices indicate the City of Fresno has a total workforce that is moderately to moderately high diverse or integrated. For example, the McIntosh and Lieberson index scores for the City of Fresno are ≈.64, whereas the MV index score is .74 (Table 3).

caption.p: Diversity Scores for the City of Fresno.

sec.p: Table 3 also shows that a number of departments have moderately to moderately high diverse workforces although they do not employ a significant number of minorities. For example, City Council has a Lieberson index score of .72, a McIntosh index score of ≈.76 and an MV index score of .84. Furthermore, the Department of Retirement which has 15 employees has a McIntosh index score of .54, a Lieberson index of ≈.59, and an MV index score of .68. By contrast, the Fire Department, which has firefighters in each ethnic or racial category, has a McIntosh index score of ≈.49, a Lieberson index score of ≈.52, and an MV index score of .60.

Table 4 shows the effect of aggregating employment data for Blacks, American Indians, Pacific Islanders, and not specified into an “Other” category to adjust for the lack of sufficient employment data. Under this scenario, the index scores suggest that the City of Fresno has a moderately high to high level of workforce diversity or integration. Specifically, Table 4 shows a Lieberson index score of .63, a McIntosh index score of ≈.79, and an MV index score of .84.

caption.p: Impact of Data Aggregation on Diversity and Integration Indices.

sec.p: Furthermore, when McIntosh and MV index scores for individual departments are reviewed, the scores suggest that a number of departments have almost achieved full workforce diversity or integration. For example, the McIntosh index score for City Council is ≈.93 and the MV index score is .95 although the department has a total staff of 32 employees. Furthermore, the Department of Transportation has a McIntosh index score of .87 and a MV index score of .91. Similar results were obtained for the Department of Parks and Recreation.

sec.title: Comparative Analysis of Diversity Indices
sec.p: Figure 1 compares the effects of data aggregation on the diversity scores. The results show that both the average McIntosh and MV scores increase as the employment data for ethnic and racial minorities are aggregated to adjust for the lack of data. When all of the City of Fresno ethnic and racial classifications are used, the McIntosh index yields an average diversity score of ≈.57, suggesting a moderate degree of workforce diversity. When the employment data are aggregated into five categories, the McIntosh index produces an average score of ≈.64, implying a moderately high level of workforce diversity. When the employment data are aggregated into two categories (i.e., White and non-White), the McIntosh index yields an average score of ≈.92, suggesting a high degree of diversity.

Figure 1 shows similar results for the MV index. Specifically, when all of the ethnic and racial classifications are used, the MV index produces an average score of ≈.67, suggesting a moderately high level of racial integration (i.e., diversity). When the employment data are aggregated into five categories, the MV index produces an average score of ≈.72. Finally, when the employment data are aggregated into two ethnic or racial categories (i.e., White and non-White), the MV index yields an average integration score of ≈.93, suggesting a high level of racial integration.

By contrast, the average Lieberson scores decrease concomitant with the data aggregation in relation to the McIntosh and MV indices (Figure 1). When all of the ethnic or racial classifications for the City of Fresno are used, the average Lieberson score is ≈.58, suggesting a moderate degree of workforce diversity. Furthermore, when five ethnic or racial classifications are used, the average Lieberson score remains at ≈.58. When two classifications (i.e., White and non-White) are used, the average Lieberson score decreases to ≈.47, implying a moderate degree of workforce diversity.
The divergent results in the index scores are the result of several factors:

list-item.p: In contrast to the McIntosh and MV indices, the Lieberson index does not have a denominator term that influences the diversity scores;
As employment data are aggregated, the MV index’s numerator remains fairly stable as the denominator term increases as a result of having fewer groups; and
The McIntosh index’s numerator term changes incrementally in relation to the denominator when employment data are aggregated.

sec.title: Implications for Diversity Measurement and Policy
sec.p: Because small agencies are likely to have few or no minority employees falling within all of the ethnic or racial classifications, the use of one or several diversity indices can lead to inaccurate inferences about the overall level of workforce diversity. Specifically, human resources administrators may incorrectly infer that an agency is more diverse in relation to another that has more minorities in each of its ethnic and racial classifications based solely on diversity scores. Furthermore, human resources administrators may incorrectly infer that because the government has an overall moderate to high diversity score, its agencies are equally diverse or integrated.

In addition, human resources administrators and researchers need to understand how employment data are used to calculate diversity scores and how the data influence an index’s score. The results presented above suggest that indices that take into account the number of groups used to quantify diversity (or integration) are likely to produce higher scores relative to indices that do not do so when data are aggregated. This issue becomes paramount when diversity indices are applied to small to moderate size agencies with small minority workforces.5

With respect to establishing a threshold in regard to a minimum amount of employment data needed to calculate diversity scores, departments with small staffs should have at least one data point for each ethnic or racial category. For instance, an agency with seven employees should have employment data for each ethnic or racial category used by the government. This general guideline applies to midsize agencies too. As the analysis above shows, the lack of sufficient employment data across all ethnic and racial categories can skew the diversity scores regardless of agency size and the index that is used.

In cases where agency staff sizes are extremely small (e.g., less than 10) and insufficient ethnic and racial data exist, the agencies should probably be rolled up into their respective reporting structures so that the overall diversity level of the hierarchical structure can be more accurate. However, this consolidation of data should be done cautiously since agency employment data will be aggregated and the diversity score will apply to the overall hierarchical structure rather than to an individual agency. Furthermore, this analysis should be done independent of the analysis of individual agencies to avoid commingling and to ensure that inferences apply solely to the hierarchical structure.

Finally, the use and interpretation of diversity indices and scores, respectively, have human resources policy implications. Diversity indices that produce conservative scores may influence human resources administrators to pursue and implement workforce diversity policies and initiatives to increase minority employment drastically when the case may be that the workforce is well integrated and diverse. Conversely, diversity indices that yield high scores may lead human resources administrators to infer that the level of workforce integration and diversity is adequate when, in reality, the employment data show that minority employment is lacking throughout individual agencies. To make appropriate policy decisions about workforce diversity in small agencies, human resources administrators need to use diversity indices cautiously and interpret the scores in conjunction with the core employment data.

sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: When applying diversity indices to small agencies, the results suggest that the Lieberson index produces more consistent diversity scores in relation to the McIntosh and MV indices in the absence of sufficient employment data. The Lieberson index also seems to be less variant when employment data are aggregated. When assessing workforce diversity in small agencies, the Lieberson index appears to be the most useful and appropriate because the number of groups within an agency does not directly influence the diversity scores. More importantly, the Lieberson seems to be most likely to lead to accurate inferences about the level of workforce diversity in small agencies relative to the McIntosh and MV indices.

Early research on racial integration in public organizations include Krislov (1967) and Subramaniam (1967).
In this article, integration refers to the employment of minority group members within an organization.
In this article, diversity refers to the extent to which an organization’s workforce falls along a continuum ranging from homogeneity to heterogeneity.
The Department of Personnel, City of Fresno, provided the employment data used in this article in February 2009.

Although this study focused exclusively on comparing racial integration and diversity across departments, the issues addressed in this study also apply when an hierarchical analysis is undertaken to assess integration and diversity across job classifications (e.g., clerical, administrative, supervisory, directors, etc.).

bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: Salomon A. Guajardo, PhD, is an associate professor of public management at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, the City University of New York. He has held executive positions in local government and has consulted with state and local governments throughout the United States. He earned his PhD in public policy research and analysis from the University of Pittsburgh.
